title: E field of distribution - E from infinite wire

content.question: An infinitely long, uniformly charged wire is parallel to the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-axis in an <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math> coordinate system, as shown in the figure. The sign of the charge on the wire is unknown. Which of the following statements makes a correct claim about the direction of the electric field <math alttext="vector E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>P</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, and provides evidence or reasoning that supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="vector E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>P</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is in the positive or negative <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction. The <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-components of field contributions from different locations on the wire cancel, leaving only an <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-component.

<math alttext="vector E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>P</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is in the positive or negative <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction. The electric field at a point is directed either toward or away from the nearest location on the charge distribution that produces the field.

<math alttext="vector E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>P</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is in the positive or negative <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-direction. The field of a charge distribution aligns along the direction of the distribution.

<math alttext="vector E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>P</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is in the positive or negative <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-direction. Most locations along the wire are far away and can be considered to contribute strongly to the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-component of the field and negligibly to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-component.

The <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-components of field contributions from different locations on the wire cancel, leaving only an <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-component.
